      <title>PPI scandal: 'serious risks' of more mis-selling in financial services market</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/13/mis-selling-ppi-financial-services-market-public-accounts-committee-compensation-claims</link>
      <description><p>Pension freedoms introduced last year could be a potential trigger for PPI-style mis-selling on a mass scale, say MPs</p><p>There are “serious risks” of further mis-selling scandals erupting in the financial services industry and stronger action is needed to tackle problems with the culture of firms, MPs have warned. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/apr/13/consumer-watchdog-warns-against-deadline-ppi-claims">Consumer watchdog warns against 2018 deadline for PPI claims</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/13/mis-selling-ppi-financial-services-market-public-accounts-committee-compensation-claims">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>China may take over Hinkley Point nuclear project, claims Lord Howell</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/china-may-take-over-hinkley-point-nuclear-project-claims-lord-howell</link>
      <description><p>Suggestion comes as EDF faces more opposition from its own private shareholders to the Hinkley scheme at its annual general meeting in Paris </p><p>Chinese companies are ready to step in and offer to build new reactors at Hinkley Point in Somerset if French company EDF backs out of the government’s flagship energy project, it has been claimed.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>EDF <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/apr/24/hinkley-point-c-nuclear-power-plant-decision-delayed-again-by-edf">recently put back a final investment decision</a> until September amid mounting problems – not least whether it has the financial muscle to construct what may be the most expensive power plant ever.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/china-may-take-over-hinkley-point-nuclear-project-claims-lord-howell">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Super-rich may quit London homes under new anti-corruption rules</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/super-rich-may-sell-london-homes-under-anti-corruption-rules</link>
      <description><p>Estate agent predicts some billionaire clients will sell property if no longer able to keep identity secret via offshore firms<br></p><p>Super-rich international investors in London property are likely to sell off some of their mansions and penthouses after the introduction of anti-corruption rules cracking down on offshore secrecy, a leading estate agent has said.</p><p>Privacy-hungry oligarchs, media owners and tech billionaires from around the world could also abandon plans to buy homes in Britain because they would no longer be able to keep their identity secret by purchasing them through offshore companies, Trevor Abrahamson told the Guardian.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/super-rich-may-sell-london-homes-under-anti-corruption-rules">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>UK steel boost as MEPs oppose giving China market economy status</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/european-parliament-votes-against-china-market-economy-status-uk-steel-industry</link>
      <description><p>European parliament votes against plan steelmakers believe would kill off industry by opening door to glut of cheap steel</p><p>UK steelmakers have cheered a European parliament resolution opposing plans that they believe would kill off the industry by permanently opening the floodgates to cheap Chinese steel.</p><p>MEPs passed a resolution saying China should not be granted market economy status by Brussels, which could make it harder for officials to impose punitive tariffs on Chinese steel. Brussels is due to make a ruling this year.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/european-parliament-votes-against-china-market-economy-status-uk-steel-industry">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Brexit could spell end for farming and car industry, says transport secretary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/13/brexit-eu-referendum-farming-car-industry</link>
      <description><p>Financial jolt triggered by departure could lead to key industries suffering same fate as coal mining, says Patrick McLoughlin</p><p>Farming and the car industry could disappear from Britain like coal mining in the 1980s because of the financial shock of leaving the EU, Patrick McLoughlin, the transport secretary, has warned.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite">Brexit could lead to recession, says Bank of England</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/13/brexit-eu-referendum-farming-car-industry">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Brexit could lead to recession, says Bank of England</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite</link>
      <description><p>Central bank issues unprecedented warning over EU vote, claiming exit could depress pound and raise unemployment<br></p><p>The Bank of England has warned for the first time that Britain could slide into recession in the aftermath of a vote to leave the EU in next month’s referendum.</p><p>Governor Mark Carney also warned Brexit could knock the pound sharply lower, stoke inflation and raise unemployment. That would leave the Bank with a difficult balancing act as it decides whether to cut, hold or raise interest rates to counter opposing forces, Carney added.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fracking in North York Moors gets go-ahead in face of protests</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/13/fracking-north-york-moors-gets-go-ahead-protests-kirby-misperton</link>
      <description><p>Council approves tests under government’s fast-tracking scheme to explore for shale gas around village of Kirby Misperton<br></p><p><br>Fracking on fields near the North York Moors national park has been given the green light for approval despite fierce opposition. </p><p>A UK firm has applied for permission under the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/13/uk-governments-fracking-definition-could-allow-drilling-without-safeguards">government’s new fast-tracking scheme</a> to explore for shale gas around the village of Kirby Misperton, provoking angry protests from environmental campaigners and locals. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/13/fracking-north-york-moors-gets-go-ahead-protests-kirby-misperton">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How £14m investigation snared Deutsche Bank insider trading ring</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/painstaking-investigation-deutsche-bank-insider-trading</link>
      <description><p>Painstaking surveillance revealed Martyn Dodgson’s links with several financiers dealing in shares via specialist knowledge</p><p>Nobody would have noticed anything odd had they been walking along the rear security wall of Buckingham Palace on 23 October 2008. Yet all around there were hidden eyes and ears trained on the activities taking place in a small office located on nearby Grosvenor Place.</p><p>For a year, a team led by the Financial Services Authority (FSA) alongside colleagues from the Serious Organised Crime Agency (Soca), had been tracking a suspected insider trading ring as part of Operation Tabernula. While they had gleaned many fascinating details, they were flummoxed by some major questions.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/painstaking-investigation-deutsche-bank-insider-trading">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/deutschebank">Deutsche Bank</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/europe-news">Europe</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/business/financial-sector">Financial sector</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/uk">UK news</category>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 12:35:03 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/painstaking-investigation-deutsche-bank-insider-trading</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/0bd9c58cabb6f4c5445276555fb33c9705c8b19b/1089_605_2407_1444/2407.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=5e53782afbeb1a2a1997598a6eb0b740">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Bloomberg/Bloomberg via Getty Images</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/0bd9c58cabb6f4c5445276555fb33c9705c8b19b/1089_605_2407_1444/2407.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=051028580bb76a97556e8b5cbfe47c6c">

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/libor-rigging-defendant-says-beaten-humiliated-work-barclays</link>
      <description><p>Barclays trader tells trial that he was given no training and was hit with mini baseball bat and often mocked, and didn’t realise rate changes were illegal </p><p>A Barclays trader accused of conspiring to fix the Libor benchmark lending rate was humiliated and “whacked” across the back of the head with a baseball bat when he made mistakes at work, a court has heard.</p><p>Jonathan Mathew started working at the bank when he was just 19, not having been to university or having had any formal training.       <description><p>One in three shareholders protest against payment to departing chairman Alan Jackson and bonuses paid to other directors</p><p>One in three shareholders in the company which owns the Frankie &amp; Benny’s, Chiquito and Garfunkel’s restaurant chains have failed to back its boardroom pay deals.</p><p>In a move that adds momentum to the wave of protests over executive pay, shareholders in the Restaurant Group protested against a payment to departing chairman Alan Jackson and bonuses paid to other directors.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/restaurant-group-shareholders-fail-to-back-boardroom-pay-deals">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Bill  and Melinda Gates Foundation divests entire holding in BP</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/bill-and-melinda-gates-foundation-divests-entire-holding-in-bp</link>
      <description><p>World’s largest health charity sells its $187m stake in the oil giant in a move welcomed by fossil fuel divestment campaigners</p><p>The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has sold off its entire holding in oil giant BP, in a move welcomed by fossil fuel divestment campaigners.<br></p><p>Bill Gates has called the selling off of coal, oil and gas stocks a “<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/oct/14/bill-gates-calls-fossil-fuel-divestment-a-false-solution">false solution</a>” to climate change, but the known investments of his foundation in major fossil fuel companies has fallen by 85% since 2014.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/bill-and-melinda-gates-foundation-divests-entire-holding-in-bp">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/inside-the-worlds-largest-cruise-ship-harmony-of-the-seas</link>
      <description><p>The giant vessel, which features a 1,400-seat theatre, a park with 12,000 plant species and a 10-storey water slide, will house 8,500 passengers and crew </p><p>The world’s biggest-ever cruise ship, the 120,000-tonne Harmony of the Seas, has opened its doors to reveal a vast floating town as it was handed over by a French shipyard to its American owners.</p><p>At 66 metres (217ft), it is the widest cruise ship ever built, while its 362m length makes it 50 metres longer than the height of the Eiffel Tower.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2016/may/13/inside-the-worlds-largest-cruise-ship-harmony-of-the-seas">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-and-uk-urge-banks-to-do-business-with-iran</link>
      <description><p>Iranian president Hassan Rouhani is under pressure from hardliners as lifting of sanctions fails to live up to expectations</p><p>An attempt by the US and UK governments to persuade European banks to do more business in Iran in the wake of last year’s nuclear deal, appears to have fallen on deaf ears.</p><p>Senior representatives from nine major banks listened on Thursday to appeals from the US secretary of state, John Kerry, and the British foreign secretary, Philip Hammond, urging them to help finance expanded trade with Iran following the lifting of sanctions under the agreement sealed in Vienna last July. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-and-uk-urge-banks-to-do-business-with-iran">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Scotland’s prosecution service says there is insufficient evidence to charge bank or directors led by Fred Goodwin</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/aug/03/rbs-sale-fred-goodwin-bailout-years-of-losses">Eight years after the £45bn taxpayer bailout of Royal Bank of Scotland</a>, prosecutors have concluded there is insufficient evidence of criminal behaviour to bring charges against the bank or any of its directors.<br></p><p>The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service, Scotland’s prosecution service, said a team of specialist forensic accountants and banking experts had examined 160,000 documents before reaching its conclusion.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/rbs-no-evidence-of-criminal-behaviour-rule-prosecutors">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/12/service-road-london-planning-permission-family-home</link>
      <description><p>Site between Victorian houses has planning permission for a three-bedroom family home<br></p><p>There’s a gap in the market for small plots of land to build on in London, so it’s perhaps no surprise that there were eight bidders for a site with planning permission in Shepherd’s Bush, west London.</p><p>Once a service road between two Victorian houses, the triangular plot has planning permission for a 13 foot-wide three-bedroom home and is about to change hands for £400,000.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/12/service-road-london-planning-permission-family-home">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/money/property">Property</category>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/first-group-budget-london-edinburgh-rail-service-trains-east-coast-mainline</link>
      <description><p>Train operator aims to compete with low-cost airlines after regulator grants it open-access rights on east coast mainline</p><p>A London to Edinburgh rail service that promises to compete with budget airlines and Virgin Trains East Coast has been given the go-ahead.</p><p>First Group will launch a rival operation, which is says will offer lower fares and an earlier arrival in the Scottish capital, from 2021 after the rail regulator granted it open-access rights on the east coast mainline.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/first-group-budget-london-edinburgh-rail-service-trains-east-coast-mainline">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Nissan buys 34% controlling share in scandal-hit Mitsubishi Motors</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/nissan-buys-share-in-scandal-hit-mitsubishi-motors</link>
      <description><p>Japan’s second-biggest car-maker vows to rebuild trust in smaller rival engulfed in fuel efficiency data scandal</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/nissan">Nissan</a> has vowed to rebuild trust in Mitsubishi Motors after taking a one-third stake in the scandal-hit car-maker.</p><p>The deal is a boost to Mitsubishi, which has been engulfed in crisis after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/apr/20/mitsubishi-motors-mishandled-fuel-economy-tests">admitting last month that it had faked data to overstate the fuel efficiency of more than 600,000 cars</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/nissan-buys-share-in-scandal-hit-mitsubishi-motors">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>ONS analysis disproves 'missing million of migrants' accusations</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/ons-short-term-migration-explains-national-insurance-gap</link>
      <description><p>Short-term migration explains national insurance ‘gap’ but discrepancy in records had fuelled claims of pro-EU cover-up</p><p>A claimed “missing million” long-term EU immigrants to Britain have been proved to be a phantom army, according to a special analysis by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) on a key issue in the run-up to the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/eu-referendum">EU referendum</a>.<br></p><p>The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/reality-check/2016/feb/26/cover-up-uk-migration-figures-reality-check">mystery gap</a> between the number of EU migrants who came to live in Britain over the last five years and the number of national insurance numbers issued to EU nationals has fuelled the highly emotive debate over immigration at the centre of the European referendum battle.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/ons-short-term-migration-explains-national-insurance-gap">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why Brexit would be the perfect gift for Vladimir Putin | Garry Kasparov</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/brexit-perfect-gift-vladimir-putin-eu</link>
      <description>An EU without Britain is exactly what the Russian president wants: a weakened institution with less power to confront his assaults on Europe’s borders<p>Politics often makes for strange bedfellows. Far-right parties in the UK and across Europe push for anything that will weaken the European Union – a goal shared by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/vladimir-putin" title="">Vladimir Putin</a> and Donald Trump. This week, their fellow Brexiteer Boris Johnson went as far as to repeat the Kremlin line that Europe is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/09/boris-johnson-cameron-cant-cut-immigration-and-stay-in-eu" title="">partly to blame for Putin’s ongoing invasion of Ukraine</a>.</p><p>One does not expect clear policy statements from Trump or Johnson, but Putin’s reasoning is irrefutable. His goal is to weaken the institutions, including Nato and the EU, that could thwart his neo-Soviet ambitions. The Kremlin was in mourning when Scotland narrowly voted to stay in the UK. Putin sees Europe as his enemy and wants his&nbsp;adversaries to be divided, smaller and weaker.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/brexit-perfect-gift-vladimir-putin-eu">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>European parliament gives China a black eye over trade status</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/european-parliament-denies-china-equal-trading-rights</link>
      <description><p>Steel dumping by Beijing has led to anti-Chinese sentiment among EU states, resulting in huge vote against giving country market economy status</p><p>The timing of the steel crisis could hardly have been worse for China. Beijing is desperate to be granted market economy status within the World Trade Organisation but is running into stiff opposition from both the US and Europe.</p><p>With Chinese steel being dumped on global markets, the European parliament on Thursday voted against the idea that China should be treated the same as the EU or the US by a thumping margin. The decision puts pressure on the European commission to either oppose market economic status outright or include safeguards for specific industries.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/european-parliament-denies-china-equal-trading-rights">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fantastically crony-capitalist: that’ll be Cameron-land | Simon Jenkins</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/crony-capitalist-corruption-david-cameron-british-tax-havens-avoidance</link>
      <description><p>It’s all very well fingering Nigeria and Afghanistan. But our war on corruption should really start with a very British predilection for tax havens and avoidance</p><p>Was it a spoof? Was it a set-up? Was it real? Like a hologram from Madame Tussauds, the Queen, the archbishop of Canterbury, the prime minister and the Speaker of the House of Commons stood in a circle, while cameras roamed round them. They instinctively defaulted to type, discussing Kipling’s <a href="http://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems-and-poets/poems/detail/46780">“lesser breeds without the law”</a>. Ma’am, said the prime minister, they’re <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/10/david-cameron-afghanistan-nigeria-possibly-most-corrupt-countries">fantastically corrupt, those Nigerians and Afghans</a>. Ho-ho, they all laughed. The archbishop did his bishop bit, suggesting the Nigerian chappie was not all bad. But did he buy his own ticket, <a href="http://www.vanguardngr.com/2016/05/nigeria-fantastically-corrupt-said/">quipped Speaker Bercow on cue</a>. Ho-ho again. The Queen added her bit at the garden party, that the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/queen-chinese-officials-very-rude-xi-jinping-state-visit">Chinese too were dreadfully rude</a>.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/nigeria-not-seeking-cameron-apology-wants-assets-back">Nigeria not seeking a Cameron apology, but 'wants its assets back'</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/crony-capitalist-corruption-david-cameron-british-tax-havens-avoidance">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Bank's warning of a Brexit double whammy is very handy for Osborne</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/banks-england-warning-brexit-double-whammy-osborne</link>
      <description><p>Chancellor will milk the Bank of England’s dire forecasts but the poor picture painted is as much due to UK structural weakness as EU referendum fears</p><p>Britain will make up its mind whether it wants to remain in the European Union in six weeks time, so it was inevitable that the last Bank of England inflation report before 23 June was dominated by the referendum.<br></p><p>And make no mistake, the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite">warning from Threadneedle Street about the likely short-term consequences of a Brexit vote</a> – including a sharp fall in the value of the pound – is mightily handy for George Osborne. The Bank assumes that there will be a double whammy of weaker growth and higher inflation in the event of a vote to leave. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/banks-england-warning-brexit-double-whammy-osborne">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Six-hour work days do boost productivity. Too bad we can't try them | Jean Hannah Edelstein</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/six-hour-work-days-boost-productivity-dont-expect-them-in-us</link>
      <description><p>For many American workers, even a 40-hour workweek is a distant fantasy. With wages low and job security in short supply that is unlikely to change</p><p>That Americans work too much is something that many Europeans accept as fact. I spent the first 10 years of my career working in the UK and Germany, but often collaborated with coworkers across the Atlantic. My European colleagues and I would raise our eyebrows at emails that we’d receive in the middle of the night from folks who were clearly working well into their evenings. We laughed at voicemails left at 8pm London time, with the preposterous assumption that we’d still be at our desks.</p><p>Relocating to New York at the beginning of 2014, my situation flipped. In a company where the majority of my colleagues were based in Berlin, we did have more vacation days than the average American worker, who gets just a paltry eight. But we sometimes struggled to get work done when my European colleagues would exercise their right to go to the beach for two or three weeks at a time. It felt like those of us who were stateside were doing something wrong.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/six-hour-work-days-boost-productivity-dont-expect-them-in-us">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why don't we talk more about the privatisation of social care?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/social-care-network/2016/may/12/why-dont-we-talk-more-about-the-privatisation-of-social-care</link>
      <description><p>We need to question the place of large private chains founded on risky financial models in providing personal care. Four tests could help</p><p>Only the oldest of social care hands will recall the impact of <a href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/30020595?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents">the Seebohm Report</a> of 1968: a strong unified local authority department; a commitment to professional development and a focus on prevention; partnership and harnessing the strengths of communities. It was all within a publicly funded and provided service – a public sector golden age that lasted little more than a decade.<br></p><p>Since 1979 there has been a remarkable shift in sectoral provision. In 1979, 64% of residential and nursing home beds were provided by local authorities or the NHS; by 2012 it was 6%. In the case of domiciliary care, 95% was directly provided by local authorities as late as 1993; by 2012 it was just 11%. This has been accompanied by a growing role for large companies with 50+ homes at the expense of small, family run businesses – five large chains now account for 20% of provision and this figure is expected to rise. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/social-care-network/2016/may/12/why-dont-we-talk-more-about-the-privatisation-of-social-care">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why Three's proposed merger with O2 was a deal too far</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/nils-pratley-on-finance/2016/may/11/o2-merger-three-deal-regulator-european-commission</link>
      <description><p>While BT is a formidable beast, trying to meet that threat with an anti-competitive deal was always going to be risky</p><p>Hurrah, a pre-referendum crisis is averted: the European Commission agrees with the UK’s regulatory watchdogs – Ofcom, on the telecoms beat, and the Competition and Markets Authority – that O2 and Three <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/11/three-takeover-of-o2-blocked-by-european-commission-on-competition-concerns">should not be allowed to merge</a>. It is not clear if voters give a damn, but they should. It would have been a nonsense if UK regulators had been left to police a mobile telephony market they had judged to be irreversibly damaged by this £10.25bn proposed deal.</p><p>Margrethe Vestager, the competition commissioner, has therefore taken the diplomatic course in blocking the merger, but there is no reason to assume diplomacy was her motive. This always looked to be a bad deal for UK consumers for several reasons.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/nils-pratley-on-finance/2016/may/11/o2-merger-three-deal-regulator-european-commission">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Tenant evictions up in England and Wales</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/12/tenant-evictions-england-wales-repossessions</link>
      <description><p>But homeowner repossessions fell to record low in first quarter of 2016 <br></p><p>The number of households evicted from rental accommodation in England and Wales rose by 5% in the first three months of the year, while the repossession rate for homeowners fell to a record low.</p><p>Seasonally adjusted <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/mortgage-and-landlord-possession-statistics-january-to-march-2016">figures from the Ministry of Justice (MoJ)</a> show there were 10,732 repossessions of rented homes by bailiffs between January and March, up from 10,253 in the final three months of 2015. The number was, however, down on the 10,855 in the first quarter of 2015.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/12/tenant-evictions-england-wales-repossessions">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Will higher rate stamp duty apply if my ex wants to buy me out?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/12/will-higher-rate-stamp-duty-apply-if-my-ex-wants-to-buy-me-out</link>
      <description><p>Confusion over new rules and how they apply to purchasing full stake in part-owned property is affecting my chances of buying a place of my own</p><p><strong>Q: </strong>I desperately need some advice on the new stamp duty rules. My boyfriend and I split up last year but we own a property together, bought in 2010, which is our primary residence. He has a buy-to-let property which is nothing to do with me (and neither of us have lived there) that he’s owned for 10 years, bought with inheritance from his grandparents. We are currently in the process of him buying me out of my half of our property so that I can buy a place of my own. </p><p>Our solicitors are saying that he will have to pay the higher rate of stamp duty land tax on this purchase, even though he is not buying a new property and this will remain his main residence. This is an increase of £7,000 on the stamp duty he was expecting to pay and he isn’t sure he can afford it, which is putting my house purchase in jeopardy. Everyone seems unsure of what is correct in this situation and we’re both extremely confused. Surely the stamp duty change was to stop people purchasing second homes, not from buying additional interest in the property they already own? Neither of us can quite believe that he will have to pay over £10,000 in stamp duty to purchase half of the house he already owns and lives in. <strong>SS</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2016/may/12/will-higher-rate-stamp-duty-apply-if-my-ex-wants-to-buy-me-out">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/ex-deutsche-bank-boss-martyn-dodgson-four-and-a-half-years-for-insider-trading</link>
      <description><p>Martyn Dodgson and ex-finance director Andrew Hind jailed for making deals on stock markets using classified information </p><p>A former Deutsche Bank managing director and an accountant have been sent to prison for “persistent, prolonged, deliberate, dishonest behaviour”, drawing a line under the UK financial watchdog’s eight-and-a-half year insider dealing inquiry.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/painstaking-investigation-deutsche-bank-insider-trading">Martyn Dodgson</a>, a 44-year-old financier who advised the government during the financial crisis, was sentenced to four-and-a-half years on Thursday for his part in an elaborate scam that prosecutors said made more than £6.9m between 2006 and 2010. It is the longest UK prison term handed down for the crime. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/ex-deutsche-bank-boss-martyn-dodgson-four-and-a-half-years-for-insider-trading">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Governor Mark Carney tells press conference that there would be a ‘material impact’ on growth if Britain votes to leave the EU </p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-growth-forecasts-brexit-interest-rates-live?page=with:block-573483f5e4b052e64fd5e929#block-573483f5e4b052e64fd5e929">Lamont blasts Mark Carney</a></li><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-growth-forecasts-brexit-interest-rates-live?page=with:block-5734798ae4b00734a22433b9#block-5734798ae4b00734a22433b9">Summary: Carney warns Brexit vote could cause recession</a></li><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-growth-forecasts-brexit-interest-rates-live?page=with:block-573470dbe4b07c8baad33493#block-573470dbe4b07c8baad33493">Carney: Everyone’s worried about referendum vote</a></li></ul><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T15:45:20.005Z">4.45pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>That’s all for tonight. Here’s our latest news story on the Bank of England’s Brexit intervention:</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite">Brexit could lead to recession, says Bank of England</a> </p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T15:44:07.407Z">4.44pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Mark Carney dire warnings over Brexit didn’t help the mood in the stock markets today.</strong></p><p>The FTSE 100 has just closed for the night, down 58 points or almost 1% at 6104. That’s the lowest level in 5 weeks.</p><p>The weakness in London has been broad-based, which should raise warning signs that this is not just a mining-related selloff. Instead, it seems investors are heading for the exits once again, threatening a further unwind of the gains made since mid-February.</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The battle for the title 'world biggest company' is about to begin. <a href="https://t.co/dnDqgtmxOM">pic.twitter.com/dnDqgtmxOM</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-growth-forecasts-brexit-interest-rates-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/11/uk-manufacturing-sector-falls-back-into-recession-steel</link>
      <description><p>Factory output was down in two consecutive quarters as the steel crisis helped drag down the sector’s overall output</p><p>Government hopes of rebalancing the UK’s service-sector-dominated economy have been dealt a blow with the <a draggable="true" href="https://www.ons.gov.uk/releases/ukindexofproductionmar2016">latest official data </a>showing industry slipping into its third downturn within a decade.</p><p>A slight pickup in activity in March was not enough to offset sharp falls in output earlier in 2016 and meant production dropped for the second successive quarter – the definition of a recession.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/11/uk-manufacturing-sector-falls-back-into-recession-steel">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Energy company has made provision for outlay to increase to almost £21bn to ensure completion of nuclear reactor</p><p>EDF, the French utility group lined up to build twin nuclear reactors at Hinkley Point in Somerset, has said the cost of the project could be £2.7bn higher than previously expected, at nearly £21bn.<br></p><p>In a statement before its annual general meeting, the state-controlled energy company said its ownership commitment on the project could rise from £12bn to £13.8bn.       <title>Cyber attack hits RBS and NatWest online customers on payday</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jul/31/rbs-and-natwest-customers-complain-of-online-problems</link>
      <description><p>Banking group says Distributed Denial of Service attack prompted flood of complaints from customers</p><p>The RBS banking group has revealed it suffered a cyber attack on its online services that left customers struggling to log on for nearly an hour – just as monthly pay cheques were arriving in accounts. <br></p><p>The group, which boasts 6.5m customers under the NatWest, RBS and Ulster brands, said it was the victim of a deliberate surge in internet traffic, called “Distributed Denial of Service”. This floods a company’s site with millions of requests, potentially bringing it to a standstill. The “distributed” version of a cyber attack involves thousands of computers under the control of one attacker.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jul/31/rbs-and-natwest-customers-complain-of-online-problems">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The German economy grew by 0.7% in first quarter, beating expectations and outpacing growth of 0.3% in the previous quarter</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T06:49:36.262Z">7.49am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p><strong>Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the euro</strong><strong>zone and business.</strong></p><p>Some upbeat news to kickstart the day. The German economy grew by 0.7% in the first quarter, more than double the 0.3% growth rate in the previous quarter.</p><p>The quarter-on-quarter comparison – following price, seasonal and calendar adjustment – shows that positive contributions mainly came from domestic demand, according to provisional calculations.</p><p>The final consumption expenditure of both households and general government increased at the beginning of the year. </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">As UK stutters, Germany's GDP grows 0.7% for the first three months of the year. Now likely to be fastest growing economy in G7</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/13/german-growth-more-than-doubles-business-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Enforcing high heels in the office is the height of workplace sexism</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/women-in-leadership/2016/may/12/enforcing-high-heels-in-the-office-is-the-height-of-workplace-sexism</link>
      <description><p>Nicola Thorp’s petition over high heels at work shows that we still believe for a woman to look professional she must also be attractive</p><p>First impressions count, even for business. It’s why the reception of any building is usually the smartest part of the office. There will be brightly coloured flowers, comfortable sofas, free water and, more often than not, a pretty young woman ready to welcome you. They’ll be wearing a full face of make-up, the smartest clothes their salary will allow, and a beaming smile. They’ll know the name of everyone in the building but nobody will know theirs. They are the first thing any visitor knows about your company and the guardian of your secrets. They’re undervalued and underpaid. And no matter how good a job they do, the one thing you will judge them on is what they look like. </p><p>I know this because I spent a year welcoming guests, pouffing the cushions and answering the phone in my best cut glass accent for a finance company. At my annual appraisal they told me I’d done a great job and they were thrilled at the effort I was putting in, there was just one thing to be improved on. Could I possibly wear more lipstick? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/women-in-leadership/2016/may/12/enforcing-high-heels-in-the-office-is-the-height-of-workplace-sexism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Too geeky for girls? Tech industry stereotypes are hindering equality</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/13/geeky-image-girls-tech-industry-stereotypes-hinder-equality</link>
      <description><p>Teachers are gradually being given the tools to get girls into computer science, but tech companies must pull their weight too<br /></p><p>For women in the tech industry, working in teams dominated by male colleagues can be a lonely experience. Studies into unconscious bias are gradually having an impact, with larger tech companies such as Google now sharing <a href="http://time.com/3904408/google-workplace-diversity/" rel="nofollow">data on its workforce diversity</a> and hiring processes. This move towards transparency is encouraging, but if tech firms really want to address the gender imbalance, the problem needs to be tackled much earlier.</p><p>Up to GCSE level in UK schools, girls are just as likely as boys to study science, technology, engineering and maths (Stem), but for A-levels and beyond <a href="https://www.google.co.uk/url?sa=t&amp;rct=j&amp;q=&amp;esrc=s&amp;source=web&amp;cd=1&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjq27f0x8rLAhUGnRoKHdRoAQIQFggdMAA&amp;url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.wisecampaign.org.uk%2Fuploads%2Fwise%2Ffiles%2FWISE_UK_Statistics_2014.pdf&amp;usg=AFQjCNGMjEHfZbiH5sfWVEBSsmuxMrdfDw&amp;sig2=gqaXVT-JyGudhxsVSe30zg" rel="nofollow">female representation falls</a> [pdf]. It’s not that girls aren’t good at these subjects. In fact, in 2014 a higher proportion of females achieved better A*- C combined grades than males in all Stemsubjects at A-level.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/13/geeky-image-girls-tech-industry-stereotypes-hinder-equality">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Putting people before profit pays off at recruitment startup</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/12/people-profit-recruitment-startup-growth</link>
      <description><p>John Langley’s commitment to his team has fuelled the rapid growth of his graduate recruitment company, Higher the Talent</p>
<ul>
 <li>John Langley was shortlisted in the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/small-business-showcase">Small Business Showcase competition</a></li>
</ul><p>When John Langley finished university in 2008, one of the worst financial crises in living memory was pummelling the UK. Banks were collapsing, many businesses were in turmoil and unemployment began to soar. It was a tough year to be a graduate looking for a job, but it was in those dark days that Langley had his first lightbulb moment.</p><p>He noticed that there was very little support for graduates to realise the full array of potential career paths and that they needed expert guidance to achieve their goals. It wasn’t until he had found success as a recruiter that this bud of an idea blossomed into a profitable business venture.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/12/people-profit-recruitment-startup-growth">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Fed's new global mandate is not without risk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/05/us-federal-reserve-global-economy-interest-rate-rise</link>
      <description><p>If the US Federal Reserve feels beholden to financial markets, the risk of sharper rate hikes will increase</p><p>“There are only two tragedies in life,” Oscar Wilde <a href="http://www.gutenberg.org/files/790/790-h/790-h.htm">wrote</a>. “One is not getting what one wants, and the other is getting it.” As the US Federal Reserve inches closer to achieving its targets for the domestic economy, it faces growing pressure to normalise monetary policy. But the domestic economy is no longer the Fed’s sole consideration in policymaking. On the contrary, America’s monetary authority has all but explicitly recognised a new mandate: promoting global financial stability.</p><p>The US Congress created the Fed in 1913 as an independent agency removed from partisan politics, tasked with ensuring domestic price stability and maximising domestic employment. Its role has expanded over time, and the Fed, along with many of its developed country counterparts, has engaged in increasingly unconventional monetary policy – quantitative easing, credit easing, forward guidance, and so on – since the 2008 global financial crisis. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/05/us-federal-reserve-global-economy-interest-rate-rise">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Crowdfunding: the boom and buzz explained</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/10/crowdfunding-explained-alternative-finance-secret-success</link>
      <description><p>This alternative finance is soaring in popularity, but what are the secrets to successful fundraising?</p><p>Crowdfunding has boomed over the past five years, with entrepreneurs pulling in over £370m via online platforms in 2015. As traditional banks have floundered, so demand for new methods of funding has risen. The <a href="http://www.nesta.org.uk/publications/pushing-boundaries-2015-uk-alternative-finance-industry-report" rel="nofollow">Pushing Boundaries report</a> by Nesta says that alternative finance, which includes a range of non-traditional online fundraising methods, has evolved from a “few plucky startups” in 2010, to an industry worth over £3.2bn in 2015. Furthermore, 2016 is the year the alternative goes mainstream, the report predicts.<br></p><p>Crowdfunding platforms such as Crowdcube, Kickstarter and Seedrs are now central to many business plans. The ability to pitch a business plan online and receive funding, in return for either equity or rewards, is an enticing idea for entrepreneurs that need investment. But entrepreneurs must understand that crowdfunding is not easy money. There are significant costs and responsibilities involved and success is far from guaranteed. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/10/crowdfunding-explained-alternative-finance-secret-success">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How badger bombs and politics brought Lush sales of £500m</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/10/badger-bombs-politics-lush-sales-500m</link>
      <description><p>Cosmetics company Lush has managed to combine record sales with controversial campaigns. Don’t expect others to copy</p><p>Lush likes to cause a stink. As well as its smelly shops and package-free produce, a large chunk of the handmade cosmetics company’s time and money is spent on political activism. </p><p>Far from carefully choosing a few business-friendly good causes, Lush has backed a plethora of controversial causes from <a href="https://uk.lush.com/article/reprieve-guantanamo-bay" rel="nofollow">Guantanamo prisoners</a>, to hunt saboteurs and the <a href="https://uk.lush.com/article/ground-frack-free-somerset" rel="nofollow">anti-fracking campaign</a>. It does this through <a href="https://uk.lush.com/article/charity-support" rel="nofollow">financial donations</a> – totalling £5m a year in 2015 - and in-store products such as the May Day bath bombs, which supported activists opposed to the badger cull. It also <a href="https://uk.lush.com/article/growing-peace-through-almond-oil" rel="nofollow">supports groups</a> in favour of peaceful resistance to the Israeli occupation of Palestine.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/10/badger-bombs-politics-lush-sales-500m">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>If you're a creative, don't let fear of figures fail you</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/09/if-creative-fear-figures-fail-freelance-cashflow</link>
      <description><p>Freelance work can be sporadic and unpredictable, but that doesn’t mean your creative venture’s cashflow has to be</p><p>Three years ago <a href="http://perpetualportraits.co.uk/" rel="nofollow">Gillian Ussher</a> quit a job she hated to make a living drawing portraits of animals. The move meant she could spend more time at home with her baby, and also pursue her passion – something which until then had only been a hobby. But while she was successful in selling her art, managing her cash flow was a battle.</p><p>“It was a bit of a disaster,” she admits. “I used to celebrate every sale by going out for a pizza and spending 50% of what we made.” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/09/if-creative-fear-figures-fail-freelance-cashflow">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Philippines investigates Shell and Exxon over climate change</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/07/climate-change-shell-exxon-philippines-fossil-fuel-companies-liability-extreme-weather</link>
      <description><p>A legal case will consider if the emissions of 50 fossil fuel companies violate the human rights of those hit by extreme weather</p><p>Can Chevron, ExxonMobil and BP be held accountable for the vulnerable communities most affected by climate change? It’s a question a legal case in the Philippines could answer.</p><p>Last month, lawyers for the petitioners met with the Commission on Human Rights of the Philippines (CHR), a constitutional body tasked with investigating human rights violations. Their goal was to identify expert witnesses for a hearing into the liability of <a href="http://www.greenpeace.org/seasia/ph/PageFiles/105904/Climate-Change-and-Human-Rights-Complaint.pdf" rel="nofollow">50 of the biggest fossil fuel companies</a> for violating the human rights of Filipinos as a result of catastrophic climate change.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/07/climate-change-shell-exxon-philippines-fossil-fuel-companies-liability-extreme-weather">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Spotted a silly sandwich board? Share photos of your favourite signs</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/06/spotted-a-silly-sandwich-board-share-photos-of-your-favourite-signs</link>
      <description><p>Whether it’s a funny poem or an inspirational quote, we want to see your photos of eye-catching sandwich boards</p><p>They may have been around since the 19th century, but savvy street-facing businesses are still using the humble sandwich board to catch the attention of curious passers-by. From inspirational quotes to dirty limericks, pubs, cafes, restaurants and shops are using humour and the element of surprise to lure punters through the door. And it appears to be working.</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/apr/29/bored-stiff-with-stuffy-advertising-then-get-board-silly">The Artillery Arms pub in east London</a>, for example, gained exposure in the national press thanks to a sign making light of a burglary at the premises during the night: “This pub is so good that someone tried to get in eight hours before we open!” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/06/spotted-a-silly-sandwich-board-share-photos-of-your-favourite-signs">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Monsanto, Dow, Syngenta: rush for mega-mergers puts food security at risk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/05/monsanto-dow-syngenta-rush-for-mega-mergers-puts-food-security-at-risk</link>
      <description><p>Recent deals in the global agrochemical and seed industry, driven by financial motivations, are a threat to farmers, prices and the environment<br></p><p>The global agrochemical and seed industry is undergoing profound upheaval, with a spate of mergers and attempted mergers consolidating the sector and raising concerns about the future of the food system.</p><p>It began last year when Monsanto started looking for a partner, trying three times (unsuccessfully) to link up with Syngenta. By the end of 2015, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/dec/11/dow-chemical-dupont-merger-dowdupont">Dow and DuPont announced</a> they were teaming up. Subject to regulatory approval, the new $130bn company – DowDuPont – plans to split into three parts, one of which will focus exclusively on agricultural chemicals and seeds and is set to command a hefty market share. It is estimated DowDuPont could account for <a href="http://www.newyorker.com/news/john-cassidy/a-dow-dupont-merger-would-raise-big-questions">around 40% of the corn and soybean seed market in the US</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/05/monsanto-dow-syngenta-rush-for-mega-mergers-puts-food-security-at-risk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>It's a game changer: recruiters make a play for ideal jobseeker</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/05/game-recruiters-jobseeker-arctic-shores-companies-candidates</link>
      <description><p>Tech startup <a href="https://www.arcticshores.com/" rel="nofollow">Arctic Shores</a> says its games-based recruiting tools better match companies and candidates and help create a diverse workforce<br /></p><p>Welcome aboard the Starship Comet – a virtual spaceship in the smartphone game Cosmic Cadet, which asks players to complete six levels of interstellar challenges in 30 minutes. The game may look and feel like Angry Birds, but it is testing more than your ability to swipe and aim. It is a psychometric assessment, which its creators believe will revolutionise the recruitment industry.</p><p>Measuring cognitive processes such as resilience and problem-solving, the game collects data on how job candidates instinctively respond to given situations, thereby helping employers gain a better understanding of how they would perform in the role and whether they are a good fit for the company. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/small-business-network/2016/may/05/game-recruiters-jobseeker-arctic-shores-companies-candidates">Continue reading...</a></description>
